title: Your First Agent in 15 Minutes
description: Set up a practical local agent loop with clear prompts, tools, and guardrails.
content:
# Your First Agent in 15 Minutes

This guide gets you from zero to a working agent loop.

## What you'll build

- A local run command
- A tiny prompt contract
- A repeatable test cycle

## Step 1: Define success

Write one sentence that describes what success means.

## Step 2: Start simple

Use one model, one tool, and one output format before adding complexity.
author: forAgents Team

title: Prompt Contracts That Don't Drift
description: Design durable system and task prompts that stay reliable over time.
content:
# Prompt Contracts That Don't Drift

Prompt drift happens when instructions become vague as workflows evolve.

## Core pattern

1. Define role and scope
2. Specify allowed tools
3. Require output schema
4. Include failure behavior

## Version prompts

Treat prompts as code. Track changes and test before rollout.
author: Kai Reflectt

title: Secure Tool Use for Agent Actions
description: Apply least-privilege tool access, validation, and audit trails for safer automation.
content:
# Secure Tool Use for Agent Actions

Security is mostly about boundaries.

## Guardrail checklist

- Restrict tool scope per task
- Validate user-controlled inputs
- Log action intent and results
- Require confirmation for destructive paths

## Red-team your routes

Create adversarial prompts and ensure your policy blocks unsafe calls.
author: Security Guild

title: Production Deployments with Confidence
description: Ship agent workflows with release checklists, rollback plans, and observability.
content:
# Production Deployments with Confidence

Deployment is a process, not a button.

## Release flow

- Stage in a sandbox
- Run regression scenarios
- Deploy behind a flag
- Monitor error and latency budgets

## Rollback first

Write rollback steps before launch day.
author: Ops Team

title: Latency Budgets for Multi-Agent Systems
description: Control response time with fan-out limits, timeouts, and cached context.
content:
# Latency Budgets for Multi-Agent Systems

Speed is a product feature.

## Where latency hides

- Serial tool chains
- Overly large context windows
- Repeated retrieval calls

## Practical fixes

Use bounded fan-out, timeout budgets, and memoized retrieval results.
author: Performance Desk

title: Agent Architecture Fundamentals
description: Learn the building blocks of planning, memory, and execution loops.
content:
# Agent Architecture Fundamentals

Every robust agent loop has three parts: decide, act, reflect.

## Components

- Planner
- Tool executor
- Memory store

## First principle

Keep each component observable so debugging is possible.
author: forAgents Team

title: Operational Playbooks for Agent Teams
description: Create runbooks for incidents, degraded tools, and fallback behavior.
content:
# Operational Playbooks for Agent Teams

Playbooks reduce panic during failures.

## Minimum runbook

1. Detection signal
2. Triage path
3. User communication
4. Recovery steps

## Practice drills

Run a monthly failure simulation and update docs after each drill.
author: Reliability Crew

title: Hardening Secrets in Deployment Pipelines
description: Prevent key leaks across CI/CD and runtime by rotating, scoping, and scanning secrets.
content:
# Hardening Secrets in Deployment Pipelines

Secrets fail most often at the seams between local, CI, and production.

## Best practices

- Use short-lived tokens
- Rotate on schedule and on incident
- Scan commits and container layers
- Separate build and runtime credentials

## Final check

Assume compromise and design fast recovery.
author: Platform Security
